subject: ASCII mappings and keyboard mappings
msgSnippet: It was very interesting to see the keyboard chart for BPJ2. Thanks Anthony! I hadn t realized before that my mappings for the half-letters #3 and #4 fall no
messageBody:
It was very interesting to see the keyboard chart for BPJ2. Thanks
Anthony! I hadn't realized before that my mappings for the
half-letters #3 and #4 fall no the keys directly adjacent to the keys
for the corresponding full letters, in that F is right below t and R
is right above d. This makes the weakest points in my mapping
stronger, although my premium will still be that the mapping be
readable when viewed in a non-QS font. Since keyboard mappings are
rather easy to customize I see the mapping as first and foremost an
ASCII transliteration of QS.

--
/ BP

It was very interesting to see the keyboard chart for BPJ2. Thanks
Anthony! I hadn't realized before that my mappings for the
half-letters #3 and #4 fall no the keys directly adjacent to the keys
for the corresponding full letters, in that F is right below t and R
is right above d. This makes the weakest points in my mapping
stronger, although my premium will still be that the mapping be
readable when viewed in a non-QS font. Since keyboard mappings are
rather easy to customize I see the mapping as first and foremost an
ASCII transliteration of QS.

-- 
/ BP
